messageBody:
Quoting Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@...>:

> > I dont think it can replace your print statements
> > because when you are printing, you are <b> discovering
> > </b> rather than <b> verifying </b>.
>
> but once you have discovered, you can verify that the class acts the
> same way over and over again. If you keep your print statements, you're
>
> discovering each time your run you tests, which is a lost of time.

What's more, you may not need your print statements to discover. Here is a
common trick I use.

Suppose I want to debug something by checking a value. I write the smallest
test case possible to get to that point. If possible, I write this assertion:

assertEquals( "", objectInUse.getValueToCheck())

This will fail and tell me what 'valueToCheck' is, instead. Now I verify by
hand and use that as the new expected value.

assertEquals( "myNewExpectedValue", objectInUse.getValueToCheck())

If the value to check is buried somewhere, then I need access to it. A
collecting parameter will help, at least until I refactor the object under test
to be easier to test on its own. With the collecting parameter, I can grab the
value at the right moment and assert its value afterwards.

ValueCollector valueCollector = new ValueCollector();
ObjectInUse objectInUse = new ObjectInUse(otherConstructorParameters,
valueCollector);
// stimulate objectInUse
assertEquals( "myExpectedValue", valueCollector.getValue().toString());

Of course, if I'm forcing myself to do a good job, I work harder at writing the
smallest possible test. I learn as much as I can about the objects that
ObjectInUse collaborates with. I refactor ObjectInUse to make it easier to fake
out its collaborators. Now I can write a really small, fast test.

Sometimes, I just put junit.framework.Assert.fail(objectToCheck.toString()) in
my production code. It's better than printing a value, because I have the exact
stack trace at my fingertips. After checking by hand, I might change it to a
useful assertion. I might even leave it in there until I can write a better
test. I try not to wait more than ten minutes before writing the test. :)
